subject: Introduced DB pooling for non blocking DB calls

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I am just starting to look at this and notice what looks like openstack common syncing mixed in with this patch.  With nova, we tend to separate these patches.  Ie, create a patch set that syncs oslo...  and then create another patch that depends on it which uses the oslo functionality that you need.

Also:  You should only sync the oslo files that you actually need.  I assume this would be limited to the db directory.

I'll review the rest of this now...

Patch Set 4:

Let me start out by saying that I'm very interested to have the tpool api wrapper from common usable in glance for the sqlalchemy driver.

However, this change unfortunately takes an approach that pours a lot of cement around existing interfaces, which are essentially legacy and unsustainable. 

1) it assumes a monolithic db api
2) it assumes certain config changes

All of this to reuse a tiny bit of code, essentially

def generic_function(name, *args, **kwargs):
    tpool.execute(self.getattr(name), *args, **kwargs)

which I'm not really that worried about duplicating across projects anyway.


I think comstud has some great ideas about how we can pare this change down, I spoke to him some about it offline.
Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Comment inline.  I don't think that'll be enough to satisfy Mark, however.

An alternative to this whole patch is to skip using oslo completely for now.  You could have sqlalchemy backend define the use_tpool option... and create a decorator that you slap onto every method in that file that wraps the call with a tpool.execute() if the conf option is on.

That would limit changes to the sqlalchemy backend... and would not complicate Mark's refactoring plans.

Mark: Is this latter option what you would prefer for now?

Patch Set 4:

We still need to have a db api interface, which would wrap the sqlalchemy method in a tpool thread. This would ensure that only the calls made to sqlalchemy api from outside are wrapped and calls within sqlalchemy do not spawn new threads.

Patch Set 4:

Eventlet takes care of that so that it does not deadlock.  It will detect if it's already running in a tpool and just run the call within the current thread.
Uploaded patch set 5.

Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 11:

It would be cool if someone could explain to me how this works exactly. How does doing the db_api call in a thread make db calls non-blocking. Or better yet, how were they blocking to begin with?

I'm assuming that sqlalchemy doing db calls is not a 'green' operation, but what does that mean exactly? Am I right when I think that this patch fixes the issue of every thread waiting on db calls to finish?

Thanks!

Patch Set 11:

Alex: Sure, I can explain.  sqlalchemy uses the mysqldb python module by default which underneath uses the C libmysqlclient.  Since the C library itself contains all of the socket code, eventlet does not/can not wrap it.  Any time we enter the C library, it blocks the current real Thread... and in openstack since we generally only have 1 real Thread, it blocks the whole process.  This same Thread is what contains all of our greenthreads so they cannot be switched to.  All DB calls run completely serially.

By using a Thread pool (real threads), we gain the ability of having multiple DB calls running in parallel because the GIL is unlocked while code within libmysqlclient is running.  Also, the original Thread with all of the greenthreads also has the ability to run.

Something like that. :)
Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 11: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I do hope we can promote that ThreadPoolWrapper code to common for use with oslo.db.

Thanks!
Patch Set 11: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved
